entry.title: Re: Material price differences between ledgers
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,


In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud the prices are updated for each Ledger (such as 0L and 2L or 3L) separately:

3445908 - Goods Issue with different values per ledger

You can check this further directly in the Material Master data (Accounting 1 view), in specific apps or CDS Views:

Feature Comparison for Material Valuations and Price Changes

CDS Views for Inventory Accounting


Best Regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Distribution ‚Äì field formula = YA divided equaly is b...
entry.content:
Hello @GizeleB 

Cash flow is not generated when the migrated condition lacks a calculation or distribution formula.

The Migration Cockpit might display the formula field as blank even if it exists, so the contract remains the ultimate source of truth.

How to Fix the Error

Verify in app Contract Management (F5273) ‚Üí Conditions.

  • If the formula YA ‚Äì divided equally is present, regenerate cash flow.
  • If it is missing, proceed to the next step

Reload the condition using the latest Migration Cockpit template, ensuring the formula column is completed like YA. Save the contract and regenerate cash flow.

If the formula still does not transfer, raise an incident with CA-GTF-MIG (Migration Cockpit) or RE-FX-CN-2CL Contract S4 HANA Public Cloud and attach one sample contract along with the CSV/XML used.

RE-FX creates cash flow only when conditions are complete. A missing formula makes the condition incomplete, so no cash flow is generated.

SAP Documentation reference userapps.support.sap.com

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytics Cloud - Data Actions - Advance Formula...
entry.content:
Hello @MoonJun - Thanks for your inputs. I have implemented the logic. This is the updated logic. I wish I could avoid the redundancy. 

Anyhow, I would close the ticket accepting your response as solution as the issue is addressed.

Thanks,

PS

CONFIG.HIERARCHY.INCLUDE_MEMBERS_NOT_IN_HIERARCHY = [d/MEASURE_TYPE], [d/HRPOSITION], [d/GL_ACCOUNT], [d/DATASRC], [d/COSTCENTER]
CONFIG.HIERARCHY = [d/COSTCENTER].[h/DA_Prompt_H1]
MEMBERSET [d/DATASRC] = ("CALC-MERIT", "CALC-REG")
MEMBERSET [d/CURRENCY] = "USD"
MEMBERSET [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = ("GL_1", "GL_2")
MEMBERSET [d/Measures] = "SALARY"
MEMBERSET [d/MEASURE_TYPE] = "M00" //Annual Salary
MEMBERSET [d/COMPANY] = %SelectCompany%
MEMBERSET [d/EMPCATE] = ("Full Time", "New", "Part Time")
MEMBERSET [d/TIME] = NEXT(0, "MONTH", %CutOffMonth%) TO NEXT(%NumberOfMonths%, "MONTH", %CutOffMonth%)
MEMBERSET [d/YEAR] = "2200"

IF [d/TIME].[p/MONTHDESC] = "Mar" OR [d/TIME].[p/MONTHDESC] = "Jun" OR [d/TIME].[p/MONTHDESC] = "Sep" OR [d/TIME].[p/MONTHDESC] = "Dec"
	THEN
	IF [d/HRPOSITION].[p/NEWPOS_FLAG] = "Y" THEN
		IF [d/SHIFT] = "08" THEN // For Salaried employees (Shift = 08), Corp Bonus should be posted to "SBC - Corp Bonus RSU" Account
			// For the New employee % to be read from assumption Table	
			DATA([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-REG", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_Salaried") =
			(RESULTLOOKUP([d/TIME] = NEXT( - 1, "MONTH"))
			 + RESULTLOOKUP([d/TIME] = NEXT( - 2, "MONTH"))
			 + RESULTLOOKUP([d/TIME] = NEXT(0, "MONTH")))
			* (RESULTLOOKUP([d/MEASURE_TYPE] = [d/HRPOSITION].[p/CORP_GRADE], [d/DATASRC] = "INPUT", [d/Measures] = "PERCENTAGE",
							[d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "#", [d/CURRENCY] = "#", [d/COSTCENTER] = "#", [d/HRPOSITION] = "#", [d/EMPLOYEE] = "#",
							[d/START_DATE] = "2200-12-31", [d/END_DATE] = "2200-12-31", [d/SHIFT] = "#", [d/TERM_DATE] = "2200-12-31",
							[d/GRADE] = "#", [d/EMPCATE] = "#", [d/EMPSTAT] = "#", [d/LABOR_TYPE] = "#"))
		ELSE // For Non-Salaried Employees (Hourly - Shift <> SA08), Corp Bonus should be posted to "Corp Bonus" Account
			// For the New employee % to be read from assumption Table	
			DATA([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-REG", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_Hourly") =
			(RESULTLOOKUP([d/TIME] = NEXT( - 1, "MONTH"))
			 + RESULTLOOKUP([d/TIME] = NEXT( - 2, "MONTH"))
			 + RESULTLOOKUP([d/TIME] = NEXT(0, "MONTH")))
			* (RESULTLOOKUP([d/MEASURE_TYPE] = [d/HRPOSITION].[p/CORP_GRADE], [d/DATASRC] = "INPUT", [d/Measures] = "PERCENTAGE",
							[d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "#", [d/CURRENCY] = "#", [d/COSTCENTER] = "#", [d/HRPOSITION] = "#", [d/EMPLOYEE] = "#",
							[d/START_DATE] = "2200-12-31", [d/END_DATE] = "2200-12-31", [d/SHIFT] = "#", [d/TERM_DATE] = "2200-12-31",
							[d/GRADE] = "#", [d/EMPCATE] = "#", [d/EMPSTAT] = "#", [d/LABOR_TYPE] = "#"))
		ENDIF
	ELSE
		IF [d/SHIFT] = "08" THEN // For Salaried employees (Shift = 08), Corp Bonus should be posted to "SBC - Corp Bonus RSU" Account
			// For the existing employee % to be read from emp attribute	
			DATA([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-REG", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_Salaried") =
			((RESULTLOOKUP([d/TIME] = NEXT( - 1, "MONTH"))
			  + RESULTLOOKUP([d/TIME] = NEXT( - 2, "MONTH"))
			  + RESULTLOOKUP([d/TIME] = NEXT(0, "MONTH")))
			 * (ATTRIBUTE([d/HRPOSITION].[p/CORP_BONUS]))) / 100
		ELSE // For Non-Salaried Employees (Hourly - Shift <> SA08), Corp Bonus should be posted to "Corp Bonus" Account
			// For the existing employee % to be read from emp attribute	
			DATA([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-REG", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_Hourly") =
			((RESULTLOOKUP([d/TIME] = NEXT( - 1, "MONTH"))
			  + RESULTLOOKUP([d/TIME] = NEXT( - 2, "MONTH"))
			  + RESULTLOOKUP([d/TIME] = NEXT(0, "MONTH")))
			 * (ATTRIBUTE([d/HRPOSITION].[p/CORP_BONUS]))) / 100
		ENDIF
	ENDIF
ENDIF

entry.title: How to perform HU based backflush from PSA using Synchronous Posting - Usage of BAdI /SCWM/EX_EWM_GI
entry.content:
Business Requirement- Material staging from Warehouse to Production Supply area( Manual Bin to Bin), part of PMR( Manual Staged Items) for batch managed items, system always follow( EWM Hard coded), GR Date and time of Batch during backflush

Customers requirement is to perform backflush on HU level from S4. HU which is moved to PSA has to be consumed first(FIFO), If product has same VFDAT with 3 different HUs, system should consume the HU based on ascending Order( HU which was staged first to PSA ). Deviation from SAP standard Batch level backflush.

 

Business Problem-Also, during a CO11N or COR6N confirmation, or using Manage Production/Process Order Apps  for an EWM storage location, batches are not selected according to the S4 defined batch determination rule (e.g. FEFO or some other LOBM Batch selection Criteria logic). However, for non-EWM storage locations, the batch determination occurs accurately according to settings. This makes customer confused as standard EWM batch determination always FIFO( GR DATE & Time of Batch) irrespective of MBC1( 261) batch condition and CU70 sorting rule opted.

Reason-  SAP has changed batch determination logic for EWM managed storage location in synchronous environment. System considers only those sort fields that correspond to a component of the /SCWM/S_STOCK_SORTED structure, such as WDATU_DATE (Goods Receipt Date), WDATU (Date and Time of Goods Receipt).

For storage locations that are relevant to Extended Warehouse Management (EWM), batch picking follows the logic established within EWM. By default, EWM sorts stocks based on the goods receipt date, ensuring efficient batch selection and processing.

Solution: If customers has batch level consumption requirement at FEFO level, customer can  set up  a stock removal rule for the storage type from which the goods are consumed in Customizing for Extended Warehouse Management under Master Data -> Define Storage Type. Also  set up stock removal rule and the sort fields in Customizing for Extended Warehouse Management under Goods Issue Process -> Strategies -> Specify Stock Removal Rule( VFDAT (Shelf Life Expiration Date). However, this only works for Single and Cross Order. For manually staged items, stock removal does not work as staging is purely manual 

However, for  HU level consumption for manually staged products as explained above a BAdI /SCWM/EX_EWM_GI_SORT_STOCK( BAdI is required: Sorting of Stock for Goods Issue in EWM) is required to sort the HUIDENT( HU) based on TRART( Process Category- Internal Movement), Warehouse Task( TANUM), confirmed date and time.

 

Replication: Below 3 HUs have been manually staged to PSA in ascending Order.

After BAdI implementation, system reads HU movement date from Warehouse to PSA in ascending Order. System should consume 804047 first, then 803913 and then 804046

Stock Situation in EWM after posting.

Performing COR6N( Process Order)

Since batch is same for all 3 Hus, S4 does not know which HU is picked.

 

Check the HU which is consumed. 803913 is consumed as per FIFO logic written in BAdI /SCWM/EX_EWM_GI_SORT_STOCK because HU 804047( B6) was blocked and BAdI has filtered the stock. 

BADI /SCWM/EX_EWM_GI_SORT_STOCK has 2 major fallback logic, use this fallback logic along with custom one.

  1.  The interface /SCWM/IF_EX_EWM_GI_SORT_STOCK has already logic to filter Blocked stocks in PSA, any HU having Blocked stocks, CO11N/COR6N will filter the stock type and hence consuming only unrestricted F2 stock type( No enhancement is needed, part of standard logic)
  2. The interface /SCWM/IF_EX_EWM_GI_SORT_STOCK has already logic to filter QI stocks from PSA. If customers have requirement to consume QI stocks use  the default implementation (class  /SCWM/CL_EI_EWM_GI_SORT_STOCK) to an own implementation of the BAdI and change the filtering logic. That way customer can  post stocks with inspection reference. Please make sure that the GI posting of QI related stock is not forbidden in  customizing.

Shift in EWM Batch Determination Logic- SAP has introduced a new batch determination class which uses /SCWM/CL_EWM_GM_BATCH_DET & /SCWM/CL_EWM_GM_QUAN_BIN_BDET . This  class is explicitly used in the SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) system that handles batch management functionalities. It includes methods for releasing stock associated with batch-managed products, managing batch details, and processing stock movements. The class interacts with various components to ensure proper handling of goods movements and batch classifications within the warehouse management processes.

Please use the above class and search all the relevant notes to get this functionality implemented at customer system. Customer may have to implement many notes to get BADI and HU based backflush in synchronous environment.

 

Thanks for reading. All the test and screen shots are performed, taken in S/4 HANA 2023 FPS02 Sandbox system.

entry.title: An invalid XML character was found in the value of attribute "description"?
entry.content:
I have been working on updating descriptions for my dimensions in Information Design Tool.  After saving my work, I closed out of IDT and later tried to reopen the business layer.  I am now getting the following message:  

Unexpected error:
org.xml.sax.SAXParseExceptionpublicId: platform:/resource/Billing%20Unlocked/retrieval-2025-05-29-19-26-35/Enterprise%20Billing%20(QA1).blx; systemId: platform:/resource/Billing%20Unlocked/retrieval-2025-05-29-19-26-35/Enterprise%20Billing%20(QA1).blx; lineNumber: 7898; columnNumber: 289; An invalid XML character (Unicode: 0x93) was found in the value of attribute "description" and element is "businessItems".

I know exactly what it is, I copied and pasted a description from a word document into the description of a dimension, accidentally, copying a hidden character.  Crazy that I was able to save it.  Is there any way to recover from this error?

hi you can try below command from Admin/PowerShell

# If folder does not exist

New-Item -ItemType Directory -Path "C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\Professional\Common7\IDE" -Force | Out-Null

entry.title: Avoiding RFC Timeout Issues During SAP Table Job Extraction in SAP Data Services
entry.content:
Avoiding RFC Timeouts: Executing SAP Table Extractions Jobs in Background via RFC Batch 

Introduction

Extracting large volumes of data from SAP systems using SAP Data Services (BODS) can be a real challenge ‚Äî especially when working with standard (non-ABAP) dataflows. One of the most common issues encountered is the dreaded RFC timeout, which occurs when a data extraction takes too long to return results, and the SAP session times out.

In many environments, using ABAP dataflows to offload processing to SAP is restricted due to governance or lack of ABAP resources. So, how can we extract large datasets without ABAP Dataflow, and still avoid timeouts?

In this blog, we explore how executing jobs in RFC batch background mode can help solve this problem.

Understanding RFC Timeouts

An RFC (Remote Function Call) allows SAP Data Services to call SAP functions like  RFC_READ_TABLE to extract data. However, when these calls are executed in dialog mode (default), they inherit the standard timeout settings of an interactive SAP user session ‚Äî typically 600 to 1800 seconds (10‚Äì30 minutes).

When a query takes too long ‚Äî due to high data volume, slow performance, or unfiltered extraction ‚Äî the RFC session times out, causing the job to fail.

What Is "Execute in Background Job in RFC Batch"?

"Execute in background job in RFC batch" means:

  • The RFC-connected extraction is not executed in foreground (interactive user session).

  • Instead, SAP submits the job to the background job scheduler, and the logic is run as a batch job.

  • This background job is still triggered via RFC but runs asynchronously, bypassing timeout limitations.

 

Benefits of Executing in RFC Batch Background

  • Avoids dialog session timeouts

  • Allows longer-running data extraction jobs

  • Reduces job failures in SAP Data Services

  • No need for ABAP code or ABAP dataflows

 

Steps to Enable Background Job Execution for SAP Table Extraction

  1. Double-click on the SAP Table:

    • In SAP Data Services Designer, double-click on the SAP table you want to extract (for example, EKKO) to open its properties.

       

  2. Open Source Table Editor:

    • This opens the Source Table Editor options for that table.

  3. Enable Background Execution:

    • In the Source Table Editor, locate and enable the option Execute in Background (Batch) .

       

       

  4. Save the Job:

    • Save your changes to the dataflow or job.

  5. Run the Job:

    • Execute the job. The extraction will now run as a background RFC batch job, preventing timeout errors typical of foreground execution.

entry.title: Re: download manager
entry.content:
The error 'The basket content could be read. Verify your logon credentials or private certificate key and try again.' typically occurs due to an incorrect password being used in the SAP Download Manager. 

Please kindly note that the SAP Download Manager does not support SAP Universal ID password, as explained in KBA 3016110 - Software download issues while using SAP Universal ID - SAP Download Manager. 

To resolve this issue, please ensure that you are using your S-user password in the SAP Download Manager, rather than your Universal ID (UID) password, which is specifically for accessing SAP for Me. If you are unsure of the password for your individual S-user ID, we recommend you using the Forgot My Password function to reset your S-user ID password by following the steps below:

  1. Go to Forgot My Password page
  2. Enter your S-user ID: S00xxxxxxxx 
  3. Click on Continue button
  4. An e-mail will be sent from SAP ID Service (ias@notifications.sap.com) to the e-mail address registered for the user.
  5. Open the e-mail to find the password reset link.

More detail on how to reset an S-user password can be found in 1808560 - How to reset an S-user ID password - SAP for Me

Hope this information is helpful to you!

Best regards,
Judy 
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: download manager
entry.content:
The error message "The basket content could not be read. Access forbidden. Check URL and try again" typically occurs when an incorrect user is used in the SAP Download Manager. Specifically, this issue arises when the P-user is used in the SAP Download Manager.

Your email address mbxxxx@haxxxxx.com is linked to both a P-user and an S-user ID. To resolve this problem, ensure that you always log into the SAP Download Manager with your S-user ID S00xxxxxxxx and the corresponding S-user password. Avoid using your Universal ID (UID) password meant for logging into SAP for Me. 

Example for reference: 
User Name: S00xxxxxxxx
Password: corresponding S-user password.

Please kindly note that the SAP Download Manager does not support SAP Universal ID password, as explained in KBA 3016110 - Software download issues while using SAP Universal ID - SAP Download Manager. 

If you are unsure of the password for your individual S-user ID S00xxxxxxxx, we recommend you using the Forgot My Password function to reset your S-user ID password by following the steps below:

  1. Go to Forgot My Password page
  2. Enter your S-user ID: S00xxxxxxxx  
  3. Click on Continue button
  4. An e-mail will be sent from SAP ID Service (ias@notifications.sap.com) to the e-mail address registered for the user.
  5. Open the e-mail to find the password reset link.

More detail on how to reset an S-user password can be found in 1808560 - How to reset an S-user ID password - SAP for Me

Hope this information is helpful to you!

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Doubts about using the API
entry.content:
1) It is possible to use this API to post invoice for both goods items and planned delivery costs. To get planned delivery costs calculated, you need to maintain Delivery Cost Condition Type parameter for the system to detect that the item refers to planned delivery costs.

Please refer to following documentations about this parameter in this ODATA API:
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/bb9f1469daf04bd894ab2167f8132a1a/b77e565e67a6480fa010c750a7ef8585.html?locale=en-US

SuplrInvcDeliveryCostCndnType    Supplier Invoice Delivery Cost Condition Type    Optional    KSCHL

2) If you would like to use this API to post credit memo, you can maintain parameter SupplierInvoiceIsCreditMemo as 'true' in the header property. Please refer to this online documentation about this parameter:
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/bb9f1469daf04bd894ab2167f8132a1a/13c22c58f5809344e10000000a4450e5.html?locale=en-US&version=LATEST

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud: Issue with Default "Tax Cal...
entry.content:
Probably, it could be due to the BP would have copied or created from a template or another BP with Brazil settings, it might have inherited that tax schema.

Please check the below areas

  • Go to CBC (Central Business Configuration) and verify the scope items activated for your project. Whether Brazil localization (e.g., BR localization content) was inadvertently included. If found, remove it from the scope and re-deploy the configuration.
  • Use SSCUI (Self-Service Configuration UI) to inspect and adjust tax settings. Navigate to Configure Tax Calculation ‚Üí SSCUI ID: 100297. This allows you to define tax calculation procedures and assign them to countries. Ensure that South Korea (KR) is correctly configured and assigned. Remove or deactivate any entries related to Brazil if they appear.
  • Check the Company Code Assignment. Sometimes tax data is derived from the company code assigned to the BP. Ensure the company code is correctly set to one that belongs to South Korea. If the company code is linked to Brazil in any way (e.g., legacy data), it could trigger the wrong tax schema.

entry.title: Re: Tax relevant accounts not defined in this area
entry.content:
This error usually stems from one of the following:

  • The bank G/L account used in F-53 has a tax category assigned in FS00, which it shouldn't.
  • The system is trying to post a tax-relevant transaction, but no tax accounts are defined for the company code or chart of accounts.
  • There's a mismatch between the tax code used and the account configuration.

Go to fs00 and check for that G/L Account, whether any value is maintained for Tax Category. If so, set it to blank

entry.title: Re: PLNKN ‚Äì Number of the Task List Node
entry.content: From table PLPO, you can fetch the value of PLNKN. You can cross-reference PLNKN with PLNNR (Task List Group) and PLNAL (Group Counter) to get a full picture of the task list structure.

entry.title: Re: Extending the functionality of eDocument for a non-lo...
entry.content: The extensibility concept for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for eDocument cannot be used in on-premise. The on-premise extensibility works differently, because as a customer you have full access to the eDocument standard classes and you can inherit from them. As a customer for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you cannot choose the language version, when creating a class. It is automatically "ABAP for Cloud Development". The interface IF_EDOCUMENT_EXT_ES became mandatory and in documentation version 2508 it is also described. It is recommended to run the database operations in the interface methods, please find more description here: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/439a34c3d6ec406a91fb29585ab0ede5/9b9b32deb6624c2cb904ccafdf88eaa0.html?locale=en-US&version=2508.500

entry.title: Discrepancy in Amount Calculation D
entry.content:
Hi,

We are currently facing an issue during the sales order generation process. Specifically, the total tax calculated at the header level does not accurately match the expected tax based on the item-wise base value.

Example:
Case No. 1

Line No Item Charge
1624.00
21248.00
33168.00
41536.00

Total: 6576.00
Applicable GST (18%): 1138.68
Expected Invoice Total: 6576.00 + 1138.68 = 7759.68

However, the system is currently rounding the total to  7758.00, which is not in line with the actual tax calculation.

We would like the final total to be accurate to the tax value and also rounded appropriately, ideally in such a way that both compliance and clarity are maintained.

Please let us know how this can be addressed or if any configuration needs to be adjusted.

entry.title: Re: PLNKN ‚Äì Number of the Task List Node
entry.content:
Greetings,

the field PLNKN defines the task list node which is an individual operation. It is used in many tables but not displayed in transactions to the user.

Bellow is an example in table PLPO which links taks list headers to operations and PLWP which links operations to maintenance packages.

We have one equipment task list - one group and two group counters. Both taks list have three operations. The second group counter is assigned to maintenance strategy and has alloscated maintenance packages.

Tables PLKO and PLPO include header and operations data. Each operation is assigned a unique NODE number.

If we inlcude table PLWP we see that packages are assigned to NODES which represent unique operations inside a task list.

For additional clarification I have created a sub operation in one of the tasklists. This operation is again represented with a node and since it is a sub operation it also has a corresponding superior operation node.

Best regards, M.

entry.title: Re: Approval Strategy for Sales Order
entry.content:
Hi,

You could implement BAdI to do your custom logic. 

1. You need to create 2 Approval request reason and create 2 Workflow in Fiori App Manage Sales Document Workflows with corresponding condition. Let say LE09 and GT09.

2. Implement your BAdI SD_APM_SET_APPROVAL_REASON to change the Value salesdocapprovalreason to LE09 or GT09 based on your logic.

You might use CDS view I_SALESORDERITEMPRICINGELEMENT or I_SALESORDERPRICINGELEMENT or extend I_SALESORDER (if needed) to get all value you need.

Thanks,

Dan

entry.title: Re: Export Software Collection in a Public Cloud environm...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question.

Currently, the systems are upgraded to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602.

Please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves your issue:

When encountering an ‚ÄòExport Failed‚Äô error without detailed information, especially after a system upgrade, there are several steps you can take to troubleshoot and resolve the issue:

  1. Check for System Locks:

    • Ensure that there are no active locks on the objects you are trying to export. Sometimes, system upgrades can leave locks that prevent further actions.

  2. Review Transport Logs:

    • Use Eclipse or other tools to check the transport logs for any indications of issues, such as locks or errors during the export process.

  3. Verify System Upgrade Status:

    • Confirm that the system upgrade has been fully completed and that all systems are on the same release version. This can affect the ability to export collections.

  4. Use Hotfix Collections: Extend and Integrate Your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Hotfix

    • If regular export fails, try using a hotfix collection. Ensure that all dependencies are resolved before attempting the export.

  5. Check Extensibility Settings:

    • Use the Extensibility Settings app to verify if the items you are trying to export support import into higher versions. This can sometimes cause export issues.

If the issue persists, please don't hesitate to reach out again.

Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Sending Emails from SAP CAP Applications with Any SMTP Provider
entry.content:
Sending Emails from SAP CAP Applications with Any SMTP Provider

Step 1: Prepare Your Mail Account

  1. Enable 2-Step Verification if your provider requires it (Gmail does).
  2. Generate an App Password or special SMTP password. This is safer than using your regular password.

        Navigate to Google Account->Security

     

 

      Search application password

      

 

 

Step 2 : Create a Destination in SAP BTP Cockpit

A destination in BTP stores connection details to external systems (in this case, Gmail SMTP).
Here‚Äôs what you do:

  1. Go to your SAP BTP Cockpit ‚Üí Destinations.
  2. Create a new destination with:
    • Name: GmailSMTP
    • Type: SMTP
    • Authentication: BasicAuthentication
    • User: 
    • Password: The 16-character App Password generated from Google
    • Additional properties like host: smtp.gmail.com and port: 587

                 

 

Step 3: Create a CAP Application

Use the CAP Template Wizard in DevSpace to generate your project. Once created:

  1. Define a service with a function for sending emails in .cds:
service CatalogService { 
    function sendMail() returns String; 
}

 

  1. Implement it in .js:
const cds = require('@sap/cds');

const SapCfMailer = require("sap-cf-mailer").default;



module.exports = cds.service.impl(function () {

    this.on('sendMail', async () => {

        try {

            const transporter = new SapCfMailer("GmailSMTP"); // Match your destination

            const result = await transporter.sendMail({

                to: "", //to list separated by comma

                cc: "", //cc list separated by comma

                subject: "Test Mail from BTP System",

                html: "Hello from CAP!",

                attachments: []

            });

            return `Email sent successfully`;

        } catch (error) {

            console.error('Error sending email:', error);

            return `Error sending email: ${error.message}`;

        }

    });

});

 

Install the mailer library:

npm i sap-cf-mailer

 

Step 4: Bind Services in Cloud Foundry

If your CAP app is new, some required services‚Äîlike destination services‚Äîmight not exist yet. In that case:

  1. Build and deploy your MTA project. Even if the deployment isn‚Äôt fully successful, the necessary services will still be created.

       

       2.Go to Cloud Foundry ‚Üí Services and bind your app to the newly created destinations.

          

         3.After binding, your .env file will automatically include the credentials you need.

 If you‚Äôre working with an existing app, you can skip the MTA build ,just bind the Cloud Foundry services, and you‚Äôre ready to go.

Let‚Äôs test: Run cds watch and call sendMail from your browser. Check your inbox, your screenshot will show the email arriving.

 

Step 5: Sending HTML Emails

You can send nicely formatted emails with HTML. Just store your HTML in a variable and pass it to the html property:

 

this.on('sendMail', async () => {

        try {

            const transporter = new SapCfMailer("GmailSMTP"); //enter destination name



            const htmlContent = `<!DOCTYPE html>

                        <html>

                        <body style="margin:0;padding:0;background:#f6f7fb;font-family:Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif;">

                            <table role="presentation" width="100%" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="background:#f6f7fb;">

                            <tr>

                                <td align="center" style="padding:24px;">

                                <table role="presentation" width="600" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="background:#ffffff;border-radius:12px;padding:24px;">

                                    <tr>

                                    <td>

                                        <h2 style="margin:0 0 12px;font-size:20px;color:#111;">Hello Mahesh üëã</h2>

                                        <p style="margin:0 0 16px;color:#333;line-height:1.5;">

                                        This is a quick test email from your SAP BTP CAP app. If you can read this, your mail setup works!

                                        </p>

                                        <p style="margin:0 0 24px;">

                                        <a href="https://example.com" style="display:inline-block;text-decoration:none;padding:10px 16px;border-radius:8px;background:#2563eb;color:#fff;">

                                            View Details

                                        </a>

                                        </p>

                                        <p style="margin:0;color:#666;font-size:12px;">

                                        ‚Äî CAP Mailer ‚Ä¢ <span style="color:#999;">Do not reply</span>

                                        </p>

                                    </td>

                                    </tr>

                                </table>

                                <p style="color:#999;font-size:12px;margin:12px 0 0;">¬© 2025 Your Company</p>

                                </td>

                            </tr>

                            </table>

                        </body>

                        </html>

`;



            const result = await transporter.sendMail({

                to: "",

                cc: "",

                subject: "Test Mail from BTP System",

                html: htmlContent,

                attachments: []

            });

            return `Email sent successfully w `;



        } catch (error) {

            console.error('Error sending email:', error);

            return `Error sending email: ${error.message}`;

        }

    });

Let‚Äôs test: Run cds watch and call sendMail from your browser. Check your inbox‚Äîyour screenshot will show the email arriving.

 

Step 6: Sending Attachments

To attach files, convert them to Base64 and include them in the attachments array:

 

this.on('sendMail', async () => {

        try {

            const transporter = new SapCfMailer("GmailSMTP"); //enter destination name

           

            const base64pdf=`JVBERi0xLjUKJeLjz9MKMSAwIG9iago8PC9UeXBlL1BhZ2UvUGFyZW50IDIgMCBSL1Jlc291

                cmNlcyA8PC9Gb250IDw8L0YxIDMgMCBSPj4+Pi9NZWRpYUJveFswIDAgNjEyIDc5Ml0vQ29u

                dGVudHMgNCAwIFI+PgplbmRvYmoKMiAwIG9iago8PC9UeXBlL1BhZ2VzL0tpZHNbMSAwIFJd

                L0NvdW50IDE+PgplbmRvYmoKMyAwIG9iago8PC9UeXBlL0ZvbnQvU3ViVHlwZS9UcnVlVHlw

                ZS9CYXNlRm9udC9UaW1lcy1Sb21hbi9FbmNvZGluZy9XaW5BbnNpRW5jb2Rpbmc+PgplbmRv

                YmoKNCAwIG9iago8PC9MZW5ndGggNjY+PnN0cmVhbQpCBiAgICAgICAgICAgIApIZWxsbyBX

                b3JsZCEKZW5kc3RyZWFtCmVuZG9iago1IDAgb2JqCjw8L1R5cGUvQ2F0YWxvZy9QYWdlcyAy

                IDAgUj4+CmVuZG9iagp4cmVmCjAgNgowMDAwMDAwMDAwIDY1NTM1IGYgCjAwMDAwMDAxMTkg

                MDAwMDAgbiAKMDAwMDAwMDY2IDAwMDAwIG4gCjAwMDAwMDAxMzAgMDAwMDAgbiAKMDAwMDAw

                MDE5MSAwMDAwMCBuIAowMDAwMDAwMjU3IDAwMDAwIG4gCnRyYWlsZXIKPDwvUm9vdCA1IDAg

                Ui9TaXplIDY+PgpzdGFydHhyZWYKMjg4CiUlRU9G

                `       ;



            const result = await transporter.sendMail({

                to: "",

                cc: "",

                subject: "Test Mail from BTP System",

                html: "Hope this goes well.",

                attachments:  [{ filename: "sample.pdf",    content: base64pdf,    encoding: "base64"  }]

            });

            return `Email sent successfully w `;



        } catch (error) {

            console.error('Error sending email:', error);

            return `Error sending email: ${error.message}`;

        }

    });

 

 

Conclusion:

By following these steps, we‚Äôve successfully sent emails directly from our SAP CAP application. The setup allows you to send plain text or richly formatted HTML emails, include multiple recipients, CCs, or attachments, and work securely using Gmail App Passwords, avoiding less secure app issues.

Everything we tested‚Äîsending a basic email, an HTML email, and attaching a PDF‚Äîworked smoothly, showing that this approach is ready for real-world use. Your CAP app can now reliably send notifications, reports, or alerts to users

entry.title: How to display multiple cover pages dynamically in single PDF - Adobe LiveCycle Designer
entry.content:
Requirement: 
To display multiple cover pages dynamically in sales quote PDF based on which cover page we need to display in the PDF.

Introduction:
This blog explains how to dynamically display cover page in a PDF based on the required cover page image, eliminating the need to create separate PDFs for each variation.

Problem Statement:
We had a requirement to display cover pages in Sales Quote custom PDF dynamically based on the cover page value (KUT field) we select in Sales Quote in SAP C4C.

Solution:
We can create multiple image fields with different cover page images as required and we can hide display only the required cover page based on cover page selected in SAP C4C and hide other cover pages in the PDF using JavaScript.

Benefits:
This method eliminates the process of creating different PDF for each cover page as we can dynamically display multiple cover pages based and selection in a single PDF, thereby reducing the development efforts of creating multiple PDF for each cover page.

Implementation Steps:
STEP 1:
Add multiple cover page images in the master page as shown below.


STEP 2:
Write JavaScript to hide the not required cover page image based on cover page image selected in SAP C4C. The JavaScript code can be written on subform level. Here in our example, we have written the JavaScript in Page3 subform.
Example:
You have two cover page image A and E in PDF. In C4C the cover page selected to display in PDF is ‚ÄúA‚Äù means in PDF image ‚ÄúE‚Äù should be hidden so that cover page ‚ÄúA‚Äù will be displayed in PDF.


STEP 3:
After completing the required changes, upload the latest PDF in ‚ÄúForm Template Maintenance‚Äù in SAP C4C and publish the upload.
Result:
Cover Page with code 111 is selected in C4C to display in PDF.


As shown in below JavaScript code if cover page code 111 needs to be displayed other cover page images are hidden


The cover page with code 111 is displayed in PDF as shown below.



Conclusion:
This blog explains how to display multiple cover pages in PDF dynamically based on selection. It will help the developer to eliminate the process of creating multiple PDF for each cover page, thereby saving time and Efforts of development.

entry.title: Targeted User Sync: Filtering in SAP Cloud Identity Services
entry.content:
Introduction


In many landscapes, user replication between SAP Cloud Identity Services and target systems is configured to include all users by default. While this approach works for smaller environments, it often leads to unnecessary data transfers, increased synchronization times, and the replication of accounts that should not have access to the target system.
This article demonstrates how to implement filtering in SAP Cloud Identity Services to ensure that only users with specific group assignments are replicated. By applying this targeted approach, you can optimize replication performance, reduce administrative overhead, and strengthen access governance across your SAP landscape.

 

References

Before we begin, it‚Äôs important to note that IAS SCIM API version 2 offers several filtering capabilities as properties. This allows us to implement the necessary transformations more easily using property-based filters.

  • üìÑSee SAP Note 3575834 ‚Äì IAS API V2 filter to read users from specific user groups in IPS and the official documentation: Source: Identity Authentication

You can find the complete list of Cloud Identity Services properties here:

  • List of Properties

For filtering, you can retrieve the required attributes via the Identity Directory API:

  • Users API (SCIM) ‚Äì In the ‚ÄúTry out‚Äù section, enter your tenant details to test queries directly. We will cover this in more detail later in the article.

Step-by-step Configuration

  1. Go to Identity Provisioning ‚Üí Source Systems in your SAP Cloud Identity Services admin console.

  2. Click the Properties tab in your source system configuration. Change the ias.api.version value to 2 to enable SCIM API v2 capabilities. Add the property ias.user.filter and specify your filtering rule. Save the changes.

    • In this example, a group-based filter is used:

groups.display eq "Test"

 

 

Extra ‚Äì How to Test Your Filter Without Updating the Configuration

If you want to verify your filtering logic before applying it to your configuration, you can test it directly using the Identity Directory API ‚Äì Try Out feature.

 

  • Go to the Try Out tab and select Add New Environment.

 

  • In the Configure New Environment dialog, fill in the following:

    • Tenant: Your IAS tenant name.

    • Display Name: Any name to identify the connection.
    • Starting URL: Leave as default https://{tenant}.{host}/scim.
    • Host: Your IAS host (e.g., accounts.ondemand.com).
    • Tenant: Your IAS tenant name.
    • Username
    • Password

 

 

 

  • Once the environment is configured, go to the Request section and enter your filter string in the filter parameter. For example:  emails.value eq "test@test.com"

 

Then click Run and review the Response section to verify that only the intended users are returned.

Conclusion

By leveraging IAS SCIM API v2 and property-based filtering, administrators can gain precise control over which users are replicated from SAP Cloud Identity Services to target systems. Implementing filtering not only improves performance by reducing unnecessary data transfers but also enhances security by ensuring that only authorized users are provisioned.

The Identity Directory API ‚Äì Try Out feature offers a safe way to validate your filters before deploying them in production, allowing for quick iteration and testing without impacting live configurations.

With these techniques, you can streamline your identity management processes, reduce administrative overhead, and maintain a cleaner, more controlled replication setup across your SAP landscape.

entry.title: Re: Plant Transfer via PO-SO Process Between GST-Register...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) answers your question?

To initiate a plant-to-plant transfer within the same company involving two different GST registrations through a Sales Order (SO) with reference to a Purchase Order (PO) in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, follow these steps:

Steps to Proceed

  1. Create a Purchase Order (PO):

    • Start by creating a Purchase Order in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system. This PO will serve as the reference for the Sales Order.

  2. Create a Sales Order (SO):

    • Use the Purchase Order created in the previous step to generate a Sales Order at the headquarters or the plant responsible for the transfer.
    • Ensure that the Sales Order references the Purchase Order to maintain the link between procurement and sales.

  3. Configure Communication Arrangements:

    • Set up communication arrangements in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to facilitate the transfer of data between the systems. This includes setting up communication users and systems.

  4. Map Purchase Orders to Sales Orders: Purchase Order to Sales Order Creation in a 2-Tier‚Ä¶

    • Use IDOCs (Intermediate Documents) to map the Purchase Orders to Sales Orders. This involves configuring the necessary IDOC types and process codes in the SAP On-Premise system.

  5. Monitor and Process IDOCs:

    • Ensure that the IDOCs are correctly processed and converted into Sales Orders in the On-Premise system.

  6. Create Outbound Delivery and Invoice:

    • Once the Sales Order is created, proceed with creating an outbound delivery and invoice for the goods being transferred.

  7. Post Goods Issue and Receipt:

    • Post the goods issue against the outbound delivery and create a goods receipt in the receiving plant.

  8. Create Inbound Invoice:

    • Use the ‚ÄòCreate Inbound Invoices for STOs - India‚Äô India - STO Processing for Interstate app to generate the inbound invoice for the receiving plant.

Important Considerations

  • Ensure that both plants have different GST registration numbers and that the necessary GST settings are configured.
  • Maintain the necessary master data information for both the supplying and receiving plants.

By following these steps, you can effectively manage the plant-to-plant transfer process through a Sales Order with reference to a Purchase Order, ensuring compliance with GST regulations and seamless integration across procurement, sales, and finance.

Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Re: How to expand default memory size for SAP S/4HANA Clo...
entry.content:
Hi @EikiK ,

the 100 GB displayed in ILM Advisor is a fixed value and is rather for illustration purpose. It does not necessarily correspond to the memory entitlement of your individual contract. For 2SL customers the default(!) memory entitlement is 100 GB, but customers can buy memory extensions. For 3SL there is a different default and also the way the memory consumption is calculated differes.
Please see Understanding HANA memory related license utilizat... - SAP Community for more details ... and please don't take the 100 GB in ILM Advisor too serious.

Best regards,

Claudia

entry.title: Re: 3D2: How can we proceed the step of preparing deliver...
entry.content:
Hello Ingrid,

Thank you very much for your question.

Please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) answers your question:

How to Include Advanced Shipment and Outbound Delivery in Scope Item 3D2

In the scope item 3D2 for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the process primarily focuses on service order management and monitoring. While the test script may not explicitly cover advanced shipment and outbound delivery, you can integrate these logistics processes by leveraging the capabilities of SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Steps to Integrate Advanced Shipment and Outbound Delivery:

  1. Service Order Creation: Begin by creating a service order in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Ensure that the service order includes the necessary details for logistics integration, such as spare parts or materials that need to be shipped.

  2. Stock Reservation: Reserve the required stock parts in a specific storage location. This can be done using the ‚ÄòManage Reservation Items‚Äô app, which allows you to edit manual reservations or stock transfer reservations created by MRP.

  3. Stock Transport Order (STO): Create a stock transport order to facilitate the transfer of stock from the warehouse to the technician van or customer location. This involves creating a purchase order of document type ‚ÄòUD‚Äô and maintaining the necessary header values.

  4. Outbound Delivery Creation: Use the ‚ÄòSchedule Delivery Creation‚Äô app to create an outbound delivery for the STO. The Power of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Processes ‚Äì Outbound Transportation Management This step involves picking, packing, and posting goods issue from the warehouse.

  5. Warehouse Tasks Execution: Execute pending warehouse tasks using the ‚ÄòRun Outbound Process ‚Äì Deliveries‚Äô app. This includes creating and confirming tasks, and posting the goods issue.

  6. Service Confirmation: After the delivery, create a service confirmation with the actual consumed quantities. This will post the goods issue for the consumed parts.

By following these steps, you can effectively integrate advanced shipment and outbound delivery into the 3D2 process, even if the test script does not explicitly cover these logistics aspects.

Additional Resources

  • For more detailed guidance, refer to SAP‚Äôs documentation on logistics integration for service orders Enhancing the Standard Part 1: Logistics integration for service orders in S/4HANA Cloud and outbound delivery processes.

[1] The Power of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Processes ‚Äì Outbound Transportation Management
[2] Enhancing the Standard Part 1: Logistics integration for service orders in S/4HANA Cloud
Kind regards, Henrike

entry.title: SAP Datasphere & Python : One click to export data of mutiple views in Excel/CSV
entry.content:
Introduction

Currently, SAP Datasphere only allows data export through Analytical Models. That means for every fact view, one has to create a separate Analytical Model just to download the data. It‚Äôs not ideal, especially when you have many views. Exporting them one by one becomes slow and repetitive.

To solve this,  Python script was developed that connects to SAP Datasphere, runs a query on each view from list, and saves the results as Excel files in a local drive path which is predefined. Now  just run the script, and it exports everything in one go‚Äîno manual effort needed.

Requirements 

Before running the script, install the following Python packages:

These packages enable secure connectivity to SAP Datasphere and support efficient data handling.

pip install hdbcli
pip install sqlalchemy
pip install sqlalchemy-hana

Creating a Database User in SAP Datasphere

To enable Python connectivity, create a database user:

  1. Navigate to Space Management in SAP Datasphere
  2. Select the relevant space
  3. Click on Database Access
  4. Create a new user with read access
  5. Copy the host, port, username, and password

Helpful links : Create DB User in Datasphere Space  

Python Script

# üì¶ Install required packages (run these in your terminal or notebook)
# pip install hdbcli              # SAP HANA database client
# pip install sqlalchemy          # SQL toolkit and ORM for Python
# pip install sqlalchemy-hana     # SAP HANA dialect for SQLAlchemy

# üìö Import necessary libraries
import pandas as pd               # For data manipulation and Excel export
from hdbcli import dbapi          # SAP HANA DBAPI for direct connection
import warnings                   # To suppress unnecessary warnings
import os                         # For file path and directory handling

# üö´ Suppress warnings for cleaner output
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

# üîê Define SAP Datasphere connection parameters
# üëâ Replace the placeholders below with your actual connection details
db_user = '<your_database_user>'           # User with access to target schema
db_password = '<your_secure_password>'     # Password (handle securely)
db_host = '<your_datasphere_host_url>'     # Host URL (e.g., xyz.hanacloud.ondemand.com)
db_port = 443                               # Default HTTPS port for SAP HANA Cloud
db_schema = '<your_schema_name>'           # Target schema containing views

# üìÅ Ensure output folder exists for Excel exports
output_folder = r'C:\Datasphere\Excel export'  # Update path as needed
os.makedirs(output_folder, exist_ok=True)

# üìã Define list of views to extract data from
# üëâ Add or modify view names based on your schema
view_list = ['VIEW_1', 'VIEW_2']  # Example views

try:
    # üåê Establish secure connection to SAP Datasphere
    connection = dbapi.connect(
        address=db_host,
        port=db_port,
        user=db_user,
        password=db_password,
        encrypt=True,
        sslValidateCertificate=True
    )
    print("‚úÖ Connected to SAP Datasphere")

    cursor = connection.cursor()

    # üîÅ Loop through each view and export its data
    for view_name in view_list:
        try:
            # üìä Construct and execute SQL query
            sql_query = f'SELECT * FROM "{db_schema}"."{view_name}"'
            print(f"üìä Executing query: {sql_query}")
            cursor.execute(sql_query)

            # üì• Fetch results and convert to DataFrame
            rows = cursor.fetchall()
            columns = [desc[0] for desc in cursor.description]
            df = pd.DataFrame(rows, columns=columns)

            # üì§ Export DataFrame to Excel
            output_path = os.path.join(output_folder, f'{view_name}.xlsx')
            df.to_excel(output_path, index=False)
            print(f"‚úÖ Data from '{view_name}' saved to: {output_path}")

        except dbapi.Error as view_err:
            print(f"‚ùå Error querying '{view_name}': {view_err}")

except dbapi.Error as db_err:
    print(f"‚ùå Database error: {db_err}")
except Exception as ex:
    print(f"‚ö†Ô∏è Unexpected error: {ex}")
finally:
    # üîí Ensure connection is closed gracefully
    if 'connection' in locals():
        connection.close()
        print("üîí Connection closed")

Script Capabilities

  • Establishes secure connection to SAP Datasphere
  • Executes queries on each listed view
  • Saves data from each view into a separate Excel file
  • Stores all files in a defined folder

Only connection details and view names need to be updated. The script handles the rest.

 One-Click Execution with a .bat File

To simplify execution, create a  RunExport.bat file to run the Python script with a double-click.

Double-clicking the file will automatically export all views to Excel without opening a terminal

 off
REM Activate Python and run the Export script

REM Change to the script directory
cd /d "C:\Datasphere\Excel export"

REM Run the Python script
python Export.py

REM Pause to keep the window open (optional)
pause

Example

Before Execution 

Double Click on "RunExcel.bat" file

Post Execution

Conclusion
This automation simplifies data exports from SAP Datasphere, especially when working with multiple views.

  • It reduces manual effort
  • improves consistency and saves time.
  • ideal for recurring tasks or scheduled jobs.

For setup support or customization, feel free to connect.

Thanks

Vikas Parmar

SAP Datasphere SAP Business Data Cloud Python

entry.title: Re: unable to configure the download manager
entry.content:
The error 'The basket content could be read. Verify your logon credentials or private certificate key and try again.' typically occurs due to an incorrect password being used in the SAP Download Manager. 

To resolve this issue, please ensure that you are using your S-user password in the SAP Download Manager, rather than your Universal ID (UID) password, which is specifically for accessing SAP for Me. Please kindly note that the SAP Download Manager does not support SAP Universal ID password, as explained in KBA 3016110 - Software download issues while using SAP Universal ID - SAP Download Manager. 

If you are unsure of the password for your individual S-user ID, please reset your S-user Password using either of the methods below: 

How to change password using SAP Account Manager(only apply to the situation that S-user ID is linked to Universal ID)

  1. Go to the SAP Account Manager
  2. Log on with your SAP Universal ID credentials
  3. Select the linked S-user ID you would like to modify
  4. Click the button with the three dots in the upper right corner
  5. Click 'Reset Password'

How to change password using Forgot My Password 

  1. Go to Forgot My Password page
  2. Enter your S-user ID: S00XXXXX890 
  3. Click on Continue button
  4. An e-mail will be sent from SAP ID Service (ias@notifications.sap.com) to the e-mail address registered for the user.
  5. Open the e-mail to find the password reset link.

More detail on how to reset an S-user password can be found in 1808560 - How to reset an S-user ID password - SAP for Me

Hope this information is helpful to you!

If you have any questions or need further assistance, please feel free to contact us.

Kind Regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Organizational Structure - SAP S/4 Hana Public Cloud
entry.content:
Organizational Structure - SAP S/4 Hana Public Cloud

In order to understand the organogram of any organization, it is essential to learn the functions of every org unit. Just like in a family, some people play the roles of guardians, supervisors and some are only dependents on elder, likewise SAP org units are. 
Every organization utilizes its resources to earn profits so from where can we extract the profitability reports? It means there is a unit made responsible to collect information, analyse and report it in every manner that is "CO-PA". (Controlling- Profitability Segment). So, Operating Concern is like a super power who sits on the top of the org structure and have all the information. In SAP Public Cloud one operating concern is predefined with name of A000 therefore CO Consultant do not need to create any other.   It is assigned to controlling area, where all variable and fixed costs of the company is stored. Just like there cannot remain two swords in one sheath, similarly two controlling areas cannot be created. In SAP Public Cloud one controlling area is predefined with name of A000 therefore CO Consultant do not need to create any other. 

The world of Finance begin when companies start trading, hence just like we have multiple universes, multiple company codes are assigned to controlling areas. Company code is the smallest org structure in FI that stores all financial documents line items. It becomes a base for MM and SD structure, an independent family member upon which other gets dependent. Company codes nomenclature can be alpha-numeric. FI Consultant will begin the org structure creation activity in SAP Public Cloud. Lets take one scenario as an example. lets say a group of companies will be made as a company and its subsidiaries will be configured as separate company codes. 

Plant is the area which is responsible to record every production activity. What is happening inside a plant, cannot be known to that person who is sitting on the head of the family chair on the dining table. (CO-PA). Therefore, MM Consultant configures the alphanumeric plants to the company codes and with this relation, correct information passes to controlling area and reports of profit gets extracted. Profit is made of Revenue-Costs, so costs are available with controlling area, but what about revenue? 

So we have another stream, another module i,e SD who is solely responsible to dispatch and record sales. Then like a river, it flows into the sea of Finance and gets connected to CO-PA. 

MM and SD are two extreme opposite sides, SD is a plus and MM is minus. (Inflows and outflows) MM has its own purchasing org, that can either be centralized or decentralized as per company's policies. 
Similarly, SD has its own sales org,  SD consultant can assign one on multiple company codes or create a decentralized structure. 

In connection to controlling area. CO consultant designs a hierarchy of cost centers and profit centers to record their activities. Purchases can be found in multiple cost centers, and via report it can be plan to control it. Whereas, sales can be assigned profitability segments to know their contributions in profit figures. 

Under plant, multiple storage locations for inventory can be configured and assigned and under the same plant, sales area is made. Sales area is the combination of sales org, divisions and distribution channel. The longest activity in org structure is of SD module.  

The material is either procured externally or produced in-house, it moves from plant to warehouse, then stamped in sales office, it dispatches from shipping points to final consumer and consumer happily transfers the receipt in company's bank account. That's how production is materialized into finance. 

Please note no consultant can begin configuration without completing the organisational structure. 

It can be edited and recreated later on. but it will lock your workspace for sometime. After doing changes, confirm the units and deploy it onto your configuration server. 

Reports are formulated with the help of transactions, if a purchase order is made in MM, check the org units, (plant, purchasing org and storage location)  will be filled, so automatically it will be assigned to its respective company code and would reach CO-PA. SD will also follow the same in its preliminary financial documents. Hence, create a strong structure to uphold the data in correct formats and form. 

Till now, we have CO-FI-MM and SD in the picture and that's how organisational structure is framed in SAP S/4 Hana Public Cloud. The role of CO is predefined, in Grey cannot be changed in any circumstances.

entry.title: Re: Upload Program to Update Equipment Status in IE02 ‚Äì I...
entry.content: Hi 'TESTNUMBER123' is not a valid object number. You need to concatenate 'IE' with your equipment number with leading zeroes. And 'TEST' is not a valid status. Take the statuses from your screenshot and check in table TJ30T for the internal object code (starting with 'E' and a 4 digit code) Lastly, keep in mind that (based on your screenshot) you are using status with status number. Which means that there is usually a sequence defined along with some logic what is allowed and what isn't. You therefore need to check your config whether your status change is allowed or not. P.S. Please read up on status management and familiarise yourself with how it works in SAP
